question.title: How to unmap a file from memory mapped using FileChannel in java?

node.contents: I hit the same problem painfully. In my case I was trying to map thousands of files into the memory and it results `OutOfMemoryError`, which I believe is the result of exhausted file handlers. Having no instrument to unmap leads to unpredictive behaviour, even though map will try to `sleep(100)` & `System.gc()` on `OutOfMemoryError` − it just postpones the convulsions.

astNode.text: I hit the same problem painfully. In my case I was trying to map thousands of files into the memory and it results `OutOfMemoryError`, which I believe is the result of exhausted file handlers. Having no instrument to unmap leads to unpredictive behaviour, even though map will try to `sleep(100)` & `System.gc()` on `OutOfMemoryError` − it just postpones the convulsions.

node.contents: I am mapping a file("sample.txt") to memory using FileChannel.map() and then closing the channel using fc.close(). After this when I write to the file using FileOutputStream, I am getting the following error:

astNode.text: I am mapping a file("sample.txt") to memory using FileChannel.map() and then closing the channel using fc.close(). After this when I write to the file using FileOutputStream, I am getting the following error:

node.contents: java.io.FileNotFoundException: sample.txt (The requested operation cannot be per formed on a file with a user-mapped section open)

astNode.text: java.io.FileNotFoundException: sample.txt (The requested operation cannot be per formed on a file with a user-mapped section open)

elements.contents: File f = new File("sample.txt"); RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile(f,"rw"); FileChannel fc = raf.getChannel(); MappedByteBuffer mbf = fc.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, fc.size()); fc.close(); raf.close(); FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(f); fos.write(str.getBytes()); fos.close();

units.rawText: File f = new File("sample.txt"); RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile(f,"rw"); FileChannel fc = raf.getChannel(); MappedByteBuffer mbf = fc.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, fc.size()); fcclose(); rafclose(); FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(f); foswrite(str.getBytes()); fosclose();

node.contents: I presume this may be due to file being still mapped to the memory even after I close the FileChannel. Am I right?. If so, how can I "unmap" the file from memory?(I can't find any methods for this in the API). Thanks.

astNode.text: I presume this may be due to file being still mapped to the memory even after I close the FileChannel. Am I right?. If so, how can I "unmap" the file from memory?(I can't find any methods for this in the API). Thanks.

node.contents: Edit: Looks like it(adding an unmap method) was submitted as RFE to sun some time back: http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4724038

astNode.text: Edit: Looks like it(adding an unmap method) was submitted as RFE to sun some time back: http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4724038

node.contents: Thanks a lot. I got it working but won't relying on System.gc() yield unexpected results on different runs?

astNode.text: Thanks a lot. I got it working but won't relying on System.gc() yield unexpected results on different runs?

node.contents: Yup. If that solved your problem, then you at least know what the problem is. Now you can decide if you want to do something crazy like loop calling `System.gc()` or reconsider your implementation.

astNode.text: Yup. If that solved your problem, then you at least know what the problem is. Now you can decide if you want to do something crazy like loop calling `System.gc()` or reconsider your implementation.

node.contents: I tried System.gc() after removing all references, but I still got the error.

astNode.text: I tried System.gc() after removing all references, but I still got the error.

node.contents: From the MappedByteBuffer javadoc:

astNode.text: From the MappedByteBuffer javadoc:

node.contents: A mapped byte buffer and the file mapping that it represents remain valid until the buffer itself is garbage-collected.

astNode.text: A mapped byte buffer and the file mapping that it represents remain valid until the buffer itself is garbage-collected.

node.contents: Try calling System.gc()? Even that's only a suggestion to the VM.

astNode.text: Try calling System.gc()? Even that's only a suggestion to the VM.

node.contents: To work around this bug in Java, I had to do the following, which will work ok for small to medium-sized files:

astNode.text: To work around this bug in Java, I had to do the following, which will work ok for small to medium-sized files:

elements.contents: // first open the file for random access RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile(file, "r"); // extract a file channel FileChannel channel = raf.getChannel(); // you can memory-map a byte-buffer, but it keeps the file locked //ByteBuffer buf = // channel.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, channel.size()); // or, since map locks the file... just read the whole file into memory ByteBuffer buf = ByteBuffer.allocate((int)file.length()); int read = channel.read(buf); // .... do something with buf channel.force(false); // doesn't help channel.close(); // doesn't help channel = null; // doesn't help buf = null; // doesn't help raf.close(); // try to make sure that this thing is closed!!!!!

fragments.text: // first open the file for random access

comments.text: // extract a file channel FileChannel channel = raf.getChannel(); // you can memory-map a byte-buffer, but it keeps the file locked //ByteBuffer buf = // channel.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, channel.size()); // or, since map locks the file... just read the whole file into memory ByteBuffer buf = ByteBuffer.allocate((int)file.length()); int read = channel.read(buf); // .... do something with buf channel.force(false); // doesn't help channel.close(); // doesn't help channel = null; // doesn't help buf = null; // doesn't help raf.close(); // try to make sure that this thing is closed!!!!!

units.rawText: // first open the file for random access RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile(file, "r"); // extract a file channel FileChannel channel = raf.getChannel(); // you can memory-map a byte-buffer, but it keeps the file locked //ByteBuffer buf = // channel.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, channel.size()); // or, since map locks the file... just read the whole file into memory ByteBuffer buf = ByteBuffer.allocate((int)file.length()); int read = channel.read(buf); // .... do something with buf channel.force(false); // doesn't help channel.close(); // doesn't help channel = null; // doesn't help buf = null; // doesn't help raf.close(); // try to make sure that this thing is closed!!!!!

node.contents: Works for us (JDK 7 64 bits, Red Hat). It avoids having compilation warnings on "sun" package (we always use the same Oracle VM in a controlled and per-defined environment)

astNode.text: Works for us (JDK 7 64 bits, Red Hat). It avoids having compilation warnings on "sun" package (we always use the same Oracle VM in a controlled and per-defined environment)

node.contents: [WinXP,SunJDK1.6] I had a mapped ByteBuffer taken from filechannel. After reading SO posts finally managed to call cleaner through reflection without any sun.* package imports. No longer file lock is lingering.

astNode.text: [WinXP,SunJDK1.6] I had a mapped ByteBuffer taken from filechannel. After reading SO posts finally managed to call cleaner through reflection without any sun.* package imports. No longer file lock is lingering.

elements.contents: FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file); FileChannel fc = fis.getChannel(); ByteBuffer cb = null; try { long size = fc.size(); cb = fc.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_ONLY, 0, size); ...do the magic... finally { try { fc.close(); } catch (Exception ex) { } try { fis.close(); } catch (Exception ex) { } closeDirectBuffer(cb); } private void closeDirectBuffer(ByteBuffer cb) { if (!cb.isDirect() return; // we could use this type cast and call functions without reflection code, // but static import from sun.* package is risky for non-SUN virtual machine. //try { ((sun.nio.ch.DirectBuffer)cb).cleaner().clean(); } catch (Exception ex) { } try { Method cleaner = cb.getClass().getMethod("cleaner"); cleaner.setAccessible(true); Method clean = Class.forName("sun.misc.Cleaner").getMethod("clean"); clean.setAccessible(true); clean.invoke(cleaner.invoke(cb)); } catch(Exception ex) { } cb = null; }

comments.text: // we could use this type cast and call functions without reflection code, // but static import from sun.* package is risky for non-SUN virtual machine. //try { ((sun.nio.ch.DirectBuffer)cb).cleaner().clean(); } catch (Exception ex) { } try { Method cleaner = cb.getClass().getMethod("cleaner"); cleaner.setAccessible(true); Method clean = Class.forName("sun.misc.Cleaner").getMethod("clean"); clean.setAccessible(true); clean.invoke(cleaner.invoke(cb)); } catch(Exception ex) { } cb = null; }

node.contents:
Ideas were taken from these posts.
* How to unmap a file from memory mapped using FileChannel in java?
* Examples of forcing freeing of native memory direct ByteBuffer has allocated, using sun.misc.Unsafe?
* https://github.com/elasticsearch/elasticsearch/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/lucene/store/bytebuffer/ByteBufferAllocator.java#L40

node.contents: This "solution" should not be used. It is both unportable and unsafe.

astNode.text: This "solution" should not be used. It is both unportable and unsafe.

node.contents: @stephancheg See my answer below for how to actually (mostly) solve this problem.

astNode.text: @stephancheg See my answer below for how to actually (mostly) solve this problem.

node.contents: @kittylyst problem should not be solved. Company should not sell its products. Developer should not be paid.

astNode.text: @kittylyst problem should not be solved. Company should not sell its products. Developer should not be paid.

node.contents: The danger is that you'll crash the JVM if the buffer is accessed again. See the comments: http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4724038

astNode.text: The danger is that you'll crash the JVM if the buffer is accessed again. See the comments: http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4724038

node.contents: Following static method could be used:

astNode.text: Following static method could be used:

elements.contents: public static void unmap(MappedByteBuffer buffer) { sun.misc.Cleaner cleaner = ((DirectBuffer) buffer).cleaner(); cleaner.clean(); }

units.rawText: public static void unmap(MappedByteBuffer buffer) { sun.misc.Cleaner cleaner = ((DirectBuffer) buffer).cleaner(); cleaner.clean(); }

node.contents: But this is unsafe solution because of following: 1) Lead to failures if someone use MappedByteBuffer after unmap 2) It relies on MappedByteBuffer implementation details

astNode.text: But this is unsafe solution because of following: 1) Lead to failures if someone use MappedByteBuffer after unmap 2) It relies on MappedByteBuffer implementation details

node.contents: This does not solve anything. Problem is not with dangling references, but with mapping itself which remains alive.

astNode.text: This does not solve anything. Problem is not with dangling references, but with mapping itself which remains alive.

node.contents: The problem is that the memory mapping causes the file to be locked at the OS level, meaning that it is impossible to write to it using non-memory-mapped operations or to delete it. This supposed solution does nothing to solve this problem.

astNode.text: The problem is that the memory mapping causes the file to be locked at the OS level, meaning that it is impossible to write to it using non-memory-mapped operations or to delete it. This supposed solution does nothing to solve this problem.

node.contents: The correct solution here is to use try-with-resources.

astNode.text: The correct solution here is to use try-with-resources.

node.contents: This allows the creation of the Channel & the other resources to be scoped to a block. Once the block exits, the Channel & other resources are gone & subsequently cannot be used (as nothing has a reference to them).

astNode.text: This allows the creation of the Channel & the other resources to be scoped to a block. Once the block exits, the Channel & other resources are gone & subsequently cannot be used (as nothing has a reference to them).

node.contents: The memory-mapping still won't be undone until the next GC run, but at least there aren't any dangling references to it.

astNode.text: The memory-mapping still won't be undone until the next GC run, but at least there aren't any dangling references to it.

node.contents: There is no way to force a GC. Not even through `System.gc()`.

astNode.text: There is no way to force a GC. Not even through `System.gc()`.

node.contents: that's why I said request

astNode.text: that's why I said request

node.contents: Just a comment about a statement made here "There is no way to force a GC. Not even through System.gc()" Actually there is. If you make sure all the application threads are idle or sleeping, System.gc() will run the GC every time, at least on Oracle's VM.

astNode.text: Just a comment about a statement made here "There is no way to force a GC. Not even through System.gc()" Actually there is. If you make sure all the application threads are idle or sleeping, System.gc() will run the GC every time, at least on Oracle's VM.

node.contents: The only way to force a GC is to provoke an `OutOfMemoryError`. The specs guarantee that before the exception is thrown, the GC was run.

astNode.text: The only way to force a GC is to provoke an `OutOfMemoryError`. The specs guarantee that before the exception is thrown, the GC was run.

node.contents: The mapped memory is used until it is freed by the garbage collector.

astNode.text: The mapped memory is used until it is freed by the garbage collector.

node.contents: From FileChannel docs

astNode.text: From FileChannel docs

node.contents: A mapping, once established, is not dependent upon the file channel that was used to create it. Closing the channel, in particular, has no effect upon the validity of the mapping.

astNode.text: A mapping, once established, is not dependent upon the file channel that was used to create it. Closing the channel, in particular, has no effect upon the validity of the mapping.

node.contents: From MappedByteBuffer java doc

astNode.text: From MappedByteBuffer java doc

node.contents: A mapped byte buffer and the file mapping that it represents remain valid until the buffer itself is garbage-collected.

astNode.text: A mapped byte buffer and the file mapping that it represents remain valid until the buffer itself is garbage-collected.

node.contents: So I would suggest ensuring there are no remaining references to the mapped byte buffer and then requesting a garbage collection.

astNode.text: So I would suggest ensuring there are no remaining references to the mapped byte buffer and then requesting a garbage collection.

node.contents: No. Use try-with-resources instead. Finalization should *never* be used.

astNode.text: No. Use try-with-resources instead. Finalization should *never* be used.

node.contents: Per the docs, finalization is the only way that unmapping occurs. Other than undocumented methods relying on sun.* classes, this is the only actual solution to the problem. Try-with-resources just closes the channel, which the OP already did anyway.

astNode.text: Per the docs, finalization is the only way that unmapping occurs. Other than undocumented methods relying on sun.* classes, this is the only actual solution to the problem. Try-with-resources just closes the channel, which the OP already did anyway.

node.contents: Doesn't the GC need to be run to determine which objects are eligible for finalization? Maybe better to call the GC and then `runFinalization`?

astNode.text: Doesn't the GC need to be run to determine which objects are eligible for finalization? Maybe better to call the GC and then `runFinalization`?

node.contents: If the mapped file buffer object can be guaranteed to be eligible for garbage collection, you don't need to GC the whole VM to get the buffer's mapped memory to be released. You can call System.runFinalization() . This will call the finalize() method on the mapped file buffer object (if it there are no references to it in your app threads) which will release the mapped memory.

astNode.text: If the mapped file buffer object can be guaranteed to be eligible for garbage collection, you don't need to GC the whole VM to get the buffer's mapped memory to be released. You can call System.runFinalization() . This will call the finalize() method on the mapped file buffer object (if it there are no references to it in your app threads) which will release the mapped memory.
